EDITORS COMMENTS

This print showcases a remarkable piece of ancient Roman art, a funerary stele with an intricate relief depicting Posidonius, his son Attalus, and his grandson Apollonius. The stele was discovered in Smyrna, Turkey and dates back to the 1st-2nd century A. D. , offering us a glimpse into the rich history of this region. Standing tall and carved from stone, this vertical bas-relief is truly awe-inspiring. The front view allows us to appreciate every detail of the carving, showcasing the skill and craftsmanship of its creator. With no people present in the image, our focus is solely on this single object that holds immense historical significance. Posidonius takes center stage in this artwork as he stands full length alongside his beloved son Attalus and adorable grandson Apollonius. Their male likenesses are beautifully depicted with great attention to detail - from their facial features to their historical clothing. As we gaze upon this masterpiece from centuries past, we can't help but marvel at how it has survived through time. It serves as a testament to the enduring legacy of ancient Rome and offers us a window into their culture and beliefs surrounding death and commemoration. This print by Universal Images Group (UIG) transports us back in time, allowing us to appreciate both the artistic brilliance behind this funerary stele as well as its historical significance within ancient Roman civilization.
